[In the previous post, Sigrid Keydana](https://blogs.rstudio.com/tensorflow/posts/2019-08-29-using-tf-from-r/) explained the logic behind the [reticulate package](https://rstudio.github.io/reticulate/) and its efficiency for interoperability between Python and R. So, this time we will build a classification model with [BERT](https://github.com/google-research/bert) taking into account one of the powerful capabilities of the reticulate package -- calling Python from R via importing Python modules.

Before we start, make sure that Python version is 3 because Python 2 can bring lots of difficulties while working with BERT model such as Unicode issues related to the text.

```{r echo=TRUE,eval=F}
# to use a preferred version of python, we nee python 3
reticulate::use_python('C:/Users/turgut.abdullayev/AppData/Local/Continuum/anaconda3/python.exe',
                       required=T)
# to see python version
reticulate::py_discover_config()
```

However, a convenient way of importing BERT model with Keras was done by Zhao HG which is called [Keras-bert](https://github.com/CyberZHG/keras-bert). This means that importing the same python library with reticulate can allow us to build a popular state-of-the-art model within R.

There are several methods to install keras-bert in Python. 

- in Jupyter Notebook, run:

```

- in Terminal (Linux, Mac OS), run:

- in Anaconda prompt (Windows,Linux,Mac OS), run:

```

## What is BERT?

BERT^[[BERT: Pre-training of Deep Bidirectional Transformers for Language Understanding](https://arxiv.org/pdf/1810.04805.pdf)] is a pre-trained deep learning model introduced by Google AI Research which has been trained on Wikipedia and BooksCorpus. It has a unique way to understand the structure of a given text. Instead of reading the text from left to right or from right to left, BERT reads the entire word sequences at once. So, it allows to understanding a word based on its surroundings. There are different kind of pre-trained BERT models but the main difference between them is trained parameters. In our case, [BERT with 12-layers, 768-hidden, 12-heads, and 110M parameters]([BERT-Base, Uncased](https://storage.googleapis.com/bert_models/2018_10_18/uncased_L-12_H-768_A-12.zip)) will be used to create a text classification model.

## Model structure

Loading a pre-trained BERT model is straightforward. Downloaded zip file contains:

- *bert_model.ckpt* which is for loading the weights from the TensorFlow checkpoint
- *bert_config.json* which is a configuration file
- *vocab.txt* which is for text tokenization

```{r}
pretrained_path = '/Users/turgutabdullayev/Downloads/uncased_L-12_H-768_A-12'
config_path = file.path(pretrained_path, 'bert_config.json')
checkpoint_path = file.path(pretrained_path, 'bert_model.ckpt')
vocab_path = file.path(pretrained_path, 'vocab.txt')
```

## Import Keras-Bert module via reticulate

Let's upload keras-bert via reticulate and prepare tokenizer object. BERT tokenizer will help us to turn words into indices.

```{r}
k_bert = import('keras_bert')
token_dict = k_bert$load_vocabulary(vocab_path)
tokenizer = k_bert$Tokenizer(token_dict)
```

### How tokenizer works?

BERT uses a WordPiece tokenization strategy. If a word is Out-of-vocabulary (OOV), then BERT will break it down into subwords. (eating => eat, ##ing).

```{r, eval=TRUE, echo=FALSE, layout="l-body-outset", fig.cap = "[BERT input representation. The input embeddings are the sum of the token embeddings, the segmentation embeddings, and the position embeddings](https://arxiv.org/pdf/1810.04805.pdf)"}
knitr::include_graphics("images/emb.png")
```

## Define model parameters and column names

Similar to Keras standard parameters: input length, batch size, epochs and learning rate should be defined for training a BERT model with Keras.

```{r}
seq_length = 50L
bch_size = 70
epochs = 1
learning_rate = 1e-4

DATA_COLUMN = 'comment_text'
LABEL_COLUMN = 'target'
```

> Note: the max input length is 512 and it is extremely computational even for GPU. 

## Load BERT model into R

We can load the BERT model and automatically pad sequences with ```seq_len``` function. This is why using keras-bert^[[Implementation of the BERT. Official pre-trained models could be loaded for feature extraction and prediction](https://github.com/CyberZHG/keras-bert)] is a better choice, it makes the loading process very easy and comfortable.

```{r}
model = k_bert$load_trained_model_from_checkpoint(
  config_path,
  checkpoint_path,
  training=T,
  trainable=T,
  seq_len=seq_length)

```

## Data structure, reading, preparation

The dataset for this post is taken from [Kaggle Jigsaw Unintended Bias in Toxicity Classification competition](https://www.kaggle.com/c/jigsaw-unintended-bias-in-toxicity-classification).

In order to prepare the dataset, we should write a preprocessing function which will read and tokenize data simultaneously. Then, we feed the outputs of the function as input for BERT model.

```{r}
# tokenize text
tokenize_fun = function(dataset) {
  c(indices, target, segments) %<-% list(list(),list(),list())
  for ( i in 1:nrow(dataset)) {
    c(indices_tok, segments_tok) %<-% tokenizer$encode(dataset[[DATA_COLUMN]][i], 
                                                       max_len=seq_length)
    indices = indices %>% append(list(as.matrix(indices_tok)))
    target = target %>% append(dataset[[LABEL_COLUMN]][i])
    segments = segments %>% append(list(as.matrix(segments_tok)))
  }
  return(list(indices,segments, target))
}
```

```{r}
# read data
dt_data = function(dir, rows_to_read){
  data = data.table::fread(dir, nrows=rows_to_read)
  c(x_train, x_segment, y_train) %<-% tokenize_fun(data)
  return(list(x_train, x_segment, y_train))
}
```

## Load dataset

As we have already written preprocess function, ```dt_data()``` function will read data, add zeros and then encode words into indices. Hence, we will have 3 output files:

- __x_train__ is input matrix for BERT
- __x_segment__ contains zeros for segment embeddings
- __y_train__ is the output target which we should predict

```{r}
c(x_train,x_segment, y_train) %<-% 
dt_data('~/Downloads/jigsaw-unintended-bias-in-toxicity-classification/train.csv',2000)
```

## Matrix format for Keras-Bert

Data is in the list format. They need to be extracted and transposed. Then, the train and segment matrices should be placed into the list.

```{r}
train = do.call(cbind,x_train) %>% t()
segments = do.call(cbind,x_segment) %>% t()
targets = do.call(cbind,y_train) %>% t()

concat = c(list(train ),list(segments))
```

## Calculate decay and warmup steps

Adam optimizer with Warmpup helps to slower learning rate at the beginning of the training process. After certain training steps, the learning rate scheduler will gradually be increased because learning new data without warmup can harm BERT model.

```{r}
c(decay_steps, warmup_steps) %<-% k_bert$calc_train_steps(
  targets %>% length(),
  batch_size=bch_size,
  epochs=epochs
)
```

## Import Keras from Python

```{r}
k = import('keras')
```

## Determine inputs and outputs, then concatenate them

In order to build a binary classification model, the output of the BERT model should contain 1 unit. Therefore, first of all, we should get input and output layers. Then, adding an additional dense layer to the output can perfectly meet our needs.

```{r}
input_1 = keras::get_layer(model,name = 'Input-Token')$input

input_2 = keras::get_layer(model,name = 'Input-Segment')$input

inputs = list(input_1,input_2)

dense = keras::get_layer(model,name = 'NSP-Dense')$output

outputs = dense %>% k$layers$Dense(units=1L, activation='sigmoid',
                         kernel_initializer=initializer_truncated_normal(stddev = 0.02),
                         name = 'output')

model = k$models$Model(inputs = inputs,outputs = outputs)
```

## Compile model and begin training 

If you have ever read [tensorflow blog](https://blogs.rstudio.com/tensorflow/), it means you are already familiar with Keras. Before training a model, we need to configure the learning process via the ```compile()``` function. And later with ```fit()``` function, we need to feed R matrices into BERT model.

```{r}
model %>% compile(
  k_bert$AdamWarmup(decay_steps=decay_steps, 
                    warmup_steps=warmup_steps, lr=learning_rate),
  loss = 'binary_crossentropy',
  metrics = 'accuracy'
)

model %>% fit(
  concat,
  targets,
  epochs=epochs,
  batch_size=bch_size, validation_split=0.2)
```

## Conclusion

There are different methods of importing BERT model into R. But as always Keras provides us with a straightforward functionality that helps to load, train BERT model with a quick and an efficient way.
